Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Social Networks and Mitigation in Areas of Chronic Disasters

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
More than half the world's population, apprxomiately 3.4 billion people, live in disaster-prone areas, and many reside under chronically hazardous conditions. The question is not why people live in highly hazardous zones, but how do people deal with associated difficulties? In this collobarative research project, Dr. Arthur Murphy of the University of North Carolina Greensboro and Dr. Linda M. Whiteford and Dr. Graham A Tobin of the University of South Florida, ask whether personal networks composed of subgroups, and links between those subgroups, provide disaster victims with advantages not available to people with either more tightly connected or sparsely distributed networks. The study builds on prior research on chronic hazards, disasters and recovery. The research will focus on communities in southern Mexico exposed to an active volcano that regularly deposits ash across the landscape. Formal and semi-formal interview data on exposure, impact, risk-perception, well-being, and personal relationships will allow researchers to ascertain how differently structured networks constrain individual outcomes and well-being.

Investigating network structures as potential strategies for decreasing the harmful effects of volcanoes poses a significant area of research and may help predict how well people respond to continual exposure to a hazard. Beyond disaster research, potential applications include community and international development, plus community resilience research. In addition, the methodological innovations proposed for this study, once tested, could be adapted to other social sciences, as well as applied to disaster mitigation and recovery efforts by outlining out how to strengthen networks that are already in existence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the context of disaster studies, there are two constants that endure and that are central to our research: people continue to live in hazardous areas and experience disasters, and their kin, friend and work networks help them recover or restore. However, networks do not necessarily serve the same functions in different places and under different circumstances. Thus, a micro-level anthropological approach to understanding support networks not only helps us be aware of these differences but also points to the skills and abilities people have for recovery and how these can be supported. In the state of Puebla, Mexico, we compared 62 personal networks of people affected by ongoing volcanic ash, personal networks of 139 people relocated following landslides, and 45 personal networks in a site unaffected by natural hazards. The structure of personal networks—or which of the people you know also know or interact with each other—provides opportunities and constraints for the dealing with extreme settings like hazards. Regarding perception of risk, people in the hazard site were more likely to be concerned about the impact of the eruptions when their personal networks had more people in them whom they felt close to, and when their networks were more dense, although the disaster site did not exhibit these correlations. We found statistically worse mental health for people with dense personal networks in both the hazard and the disaster site, but not the control site. Additionally, household conditions were worse for people with more dense personal networks in the hazard site, but in the disaster site were worse for the very dense networks and the least dense networks. These results suggests that personal support and personal networks do not work the same way in every site, but that consideration of the opportunities and constraints provided by people’s social relationships can be important for disaster recovery.  This finding is important in efforts to develop post disaster recovery strategies in general and particularly so when considering populations with a Latino cultural heritage.
